item.title: Why Trade Deals and Tax Cuts May Be a Recipe for US Success
item.description: On this week’s Trumponomics, Stephen Moore of the Heritage Foundation argues that Donald Trump and the GOP Congress are on the right path.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Stephen Moore, visiting fellow at the Heritage Foundation, listens during a discussion at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland, U.S., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. President Trump will address this years CPAC after seeking to close ranks within his administration about the threat posed by the coronavirus and how the U.S. government plans to stop its spread following mixed messages that rattled Wall Street.

item.title: Peru’s Endless Political Churn Is Spreading to the Finance Minister Post
item.description: Peru’s messy cabinet reshuffle is spotlighting how political instability is spreading to what was once a treasured post: the finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun, Maria Elena Vizcaino

media:content.media:description: Dina Boluarte Photographer: Carlos Garcia Granthon/Fotoholica Press/LightRocket/Getty Images

item.title: UK Mulls New Investor Visa Targeting Key Strategic Industries
item.description: The UK is drawing up plans for a special visa for foreigners who invest significant sums in Britain, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government seeks to blunt the economic blow from recent tax hikes and wider curbs on work permits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Alex Wickham

item.title: Carney Delays Canada Budget, Plans to Cut Income Tax by July
item.description: Canada will cut the lowest personal income tax rate to 14% from 15% on July 1, but Prime Minister Mark Carney’s new government won’t release a budget before the summer months.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney during a news conference with cabinet members after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, on May 13.

item.title: US May Need a Bond-Market Blowup to Cut Deficit, Market Veteran Says
item.description: After the November election, there were few people in the bond market more optimistic about how President Donald Trump, and his band of DOGE cost-cutters, would rein in ballooning budget deficits than Stephen Jen.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: Argentina Inflation Slowed in April Amid Peso Policy Change
item.description: Argentina’s inflation slowed down more than expected in April despite a change in the currency policy traders were betting would fan volatility.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Shoppers browse products in a supermarket in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

item.title: Angola’s Fight Against Graft Is Losing Momentum, IMF Says
item.description: Angolan President Joao Lourenco’s anti-corruption drive is losing steam, putting the country’s economic growth outlook at risk, according to the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Candido Mendes

media:content.media:description: Joao Lourenco

item.title: Weaker Dollar Said Not to Be Part of US Tariff Negotiations
item.description: US officials seeking to negotiate trade deals around the world are not working to include currency policy pledges in the agreements, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin

item.title: Trump Capitulates, But Buyer Beware
item.description: Now that the trade war between the US and China has de-escalated, everyone on Wall Street seems to think the risk of recession is greatly diminished. This suggests that Treasury yields will rise because the Federal Reserve won’t need to save the day.
item.dc:creator: Edward Harrison

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 9, 2025. Trump said that he would always impose a minimum 10% tariff on trading partners, before quickly adding that there could be an exception, underscoring the difficulty discerning the US approach to dozens of trade deals under negotiation. Photographer: Yuri Gripas/Abaca

item.title: China Pauses Rare Earths Exports Curbs Targeting US Entities
item.description: China on Wednesday suspended curbs on exports of rare earths and other goods and technologies for military use targeting 28 US entities as part of the trade detente struck between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Li Liu

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles.

item.title: Lula and Xi Agree to Boost Chinese Presence in Brazil Despite Trump's Threats
item.description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva insists he doesn’t want to pick between the US and China as his two largest trading partners wage a trade war. But it’s increasingly clear which side he has already chosen.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Leonardo Lara, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in 2024.

item.title: Canada’s New Tariffs on US Drop to ‘Nearly Zero’ With Exemptions, Oxford Says
item.description: Canada has effectively suspended almost all of its retaliatory tariffs on US products, tamping down inflation risks and improving its growth outlook, according to Oxford Economics.
item.dc:creator: Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: A truck crosses the Peace Bridge at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. US President Trump on April 2 plans to roll out tariffs on global trading partners, the centerpiece of his effort to bring back manufacturing to the US and reshape a world trade system he has long decried as unfair.

item.title: Brazil Needs Fiscal Sense to Gain From Trade War, Speaker Says
item.description: Brazil has emerged as an early winner from Donald Trump’s trade war with China but needs to get its fiscal situation in order to attract investment and fully capitalize on the global upheaval, according to lower house Speaker Hugo Motta.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho, Vanessa Dezem

media:content.media:description: Hugo Motta Photographer: Raul Luciano/Agencia Estado/AP Images

item.title: Gold’s Rally Spurs Turkish Hoarders to Splurge on Homes and Cars
item.description: Soaring gold prices are prompting Turkish households to convert their bullion savings into big-ticket purchases, especially homes and cars, according to a new study by the country’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz

media:content.media:description: A robot pours gold granules into molds at a refinery smelter in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Fed’s Jefferson Sees Lower Growth, Says Inflation Could Rise
item.description: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Philip Jefferson said tariffs and related uncertainty could slow growth and boost inflation this year, but monetary policy is well positioned to respond as needed.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Philip Jefferson Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed Must Be Steady Hand Amid Stock, Policy Moves, Goolsbee Says
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee said that it’s important for central bankers not to respond to day-to-day volatility in equities and economic policy pronouncements, noting that economic data remain steady for now.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Japan to Target 1% Real Wage Gains Within Next Five Years
item.description: The Japanese government is likely to establish 1% growth in real wages as its first-ever official target for pay increases, a move that comes as prolonged inflation continues to exert a drag on domestic demand.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the Ginza district of Tokyo.

item.title: How Milei Keeps Argentina’s Peso Strong Ahead of Midterm Vote
item.description: Five months ahead of crucial midterm elections in Argentina, the peso has become the cornerstone of Javier Milei’s campaign strategy.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: Argentina's currency has been trading below the midpoint of the 1,000 to 1,400 pesos per dollar band the government initially set on April 11. Photographer: Erica Canepa/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Tax Plan Gains Momentum in House as It Heads to Floor Vote
item.description: President Donald Trump’s signature economic package took a major step toward becoming law when the House Ways and Means Committee approved trillions in new tax cuts for corporations, households and small businesses on a party-line vote.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Chris Cioffi, Zach C Cohen

media:content.media:description: Jason Smith, center, during a markup of the tax package in Washington, DC, on May 13.

item.title: Turkish Central Banker Warns of Prolonged Period of High Rates
item.description: Turkey’s interest rates will need to stay elevated for longer unless individuals and companies have faith the central bank is committed to slowing inflation and adjust buying and pricing patterns, Deputy Governor Cevdet Akcay said.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Osman Cevdet Akcay in Brussels, on May 13, 2025.

item.title: Hapag-Lloyd Sees Bookings Jump After US-China Tariff Truce
item.description: Just a few weeks ago, things weren’t looking so great for container shipping lines. Spot freight rates were sagging, demand visibility was near zero and an escalating trade war between the world’s largest economies dimmed the outlook for the industry’s lifeblood — global commerce.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: A Tariff-Cost Reality Check for Small Business After China Truce
item.description: I’m Enda Curran, a US economy reporter in Washington. Today we’re looking at US small business and tariffs. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

item.title: BOE Looks to Tame Risks From Leveraged UK Bond Trades
item.description: The Bank of England will consult investors on how to improve UK bond market resilience in order to avoid a repeat of the 2022 gilt crisis.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie, Alice Atkins

media:content.media:description: The Bank of England in the City of London.

item.title: Tariffs Won’t Reindustrialize America. Here’s What Will
item.description: To revive manufacturing the US needs to borrow from China’s playbook.
item.dc:creator: Dan Wang, Ben Reinhardt

item.title: ECB’s Nagel Says US Tariff News Almost Caused Financial Meltdown
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Joachim Nagel said financial markets were close to a meltdown after last month’s US trade announcements, highlighting their vulnerability to erratic economic policies.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

item.title: Expert Panel Suggests Japan’s Government Make Childbirth Free
item.description: The Japanese government should cover out-of-pocket childbirth fees, an expert panel said, as the aging nation seeks to reverse its declining population and shrinking pool of tax-paying workers.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: A woman carrying a baby at a store in Kyoto.

item.title: Perry Mehrling on Trump's Echoes of the Nixon Shock
item.description: Will history repeat?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump displays a signed executive order in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC.

item.title: Odd Lots: Perry Mehrling on Trump’s Nixon Shock Echoes (Podcast)
item.description: There’s been a lot of talk recently about parallels between Donald Trump’s economic policies and the Nixon Shock of the early 1970s. That was when the former president took the dollar off the gold standard, introduced hefty tariffs, and pressured the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy. The moves sparked stagflation in the US and shook up the global monetary order. Now, given Trump’s determination to rebalance the US relationship with global trading partners and his criticism of the Fed, cou
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: BOE’s Mann Says Market Moves Stopped Her Backing More Rate Cuts
item.description: Bank of England rate-setter Catherine Mann said she flipped her vote from a bumper interest-rate cut to a pause because sharp moves on markets had lowered borrowing costs and provided enough easing of financial conditions.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Catherine Mann

item.title: Vietnam PM Orders Crackdown on Trade Fraud, Counterfeit Goods
item.description: Vietnam’s prime minister vowed to step up the fight against trade fraud, smuggling and counterfeit goods, as the nation seeks to address longstanding issues that have proved a sticking point in US tariff negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Pham Minh Chinh
